text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -but the Aliguard’s okay right? Patient: Aliguard is okay. I'm tired. Yeah, but it doesn’t totally destabilize my life. Doctor: Right, right. I think when you get off the Xtandi, you're actually gonna feel a little bit better. Because you know, at four pills a day does weigh on you. So I think that would be better. But I'm gonna talk to S____, our research nurse who's covering for M____ who's our regular research nurse. But S___ will come in here and will just go over and see how you feel about it. You know if you're interested, great. We'll move forward and do what we need to do. We have to check to make sure all these lovely things can stay on and if not, we do regular chemo. Family Member: Well, it makes me feel good is one big concern. I get is that if he starts getting so much bone loss he can't function and his quality of life and if you can zap areas at which I didn't know. Yeah, it makes me realize hey he can have a quality of life. Doctor: Oh yeah that's number one. Family Member: There you go S___. Doctor: Living is very important but we can't do it with you laid up in bed doing nothing and just say well it's good we got the prostate cancer all taken care of. Family Member: Right that’s not good. Doctor: I say that all the time too. Patient: The one on my ribs doesn't bother me. Doctor: It doesn’t bother you. Patient: That doesn’t bother me. The one that frightens me is the one’s going up and down my spine.

text: Patient: Yeah, who wants to Doctor: He was like well, um, I have a person here who claims to be your patient. I’m like I don’t know where here is, right, but his name is blah, blah, blah. So, the thing is that particular patient we’re always joking around so I’m like is this guy punking me at nine p.m. at night and I was about just this close to going nope, never heard of him, right, but somewhere in the recesses of my mind I’m like maybe this sounds more serious. I go yes and he goes okay, well, anyways we’re at the border patrol. Patient: Oh, wow. Doctor: He set off the sensors. They went on full lock down, like everything, Patient: Oh, geez Doctor: like guns drawn because they thought he was like transporting plutonium or something. Patient: Oh, my God! Wow Doctor: But I didn’t know it was my patient because rightly so they didn’t allow him to call from his cellphone. Patient: That makes sense. Doctor: So they had to call from the border. Oh, man! So then I was like oh, my gosh, then I was like well, how do I know you are who you say you are so I gave it right back to him and I go so, you know, what’s your phone number so just to be safe I called the guy back. I was like I don’t know who this person is, you know, it might be… Patient: Right, that’s a good point. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah and then, you know, there he was.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: And that the tube itself is going to make a channel that has to be in the six-week time so that the channel can sort of get wide enough so that pee comes out, okay. And that’s why they are worried about shall we take it out, shall we not take it out, you should have left it in. And if it’s obstructed it’s got to come out or your kidney function gets bad again. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And that’s why they’re saying it needs to be changed every four to six weeks so that it doesn’t get blocked. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so now the issue is they’re going to probably be doing a lot of voiding trials to see whether or not you can pee on your own. You know do they clamp it and you feel like okay I’ve got to pee and then you can sort of see if you can get it out. So that’s what the urologists are going to be doing. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So on the clinical study, we do scan him more than he would get if he was not on the clinical trial because we’re giving you more therapy than what’s usual, and they wouldn’t want us to keep giving you drugs that they’re not helping, and so they They want the actual data about scans. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So that would be a potential good thing for you. If you want more information, the study gives you more of that information. Family Member: Right. Doctor: But how I make decisions, I don’t necessarily need those scans.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
